intro: Aa pumilio, commonly known as the dwarf tree fern, is a species native to tropical regions of the Americas. It is characterized by its compact, bushy form with a short trunk and a dense crown of feathery fronds. The plant features a root system that helps anchor it in moist, shaded environments. Its fronds are typically light green and can grow up to several feet in length. Aa pumilio thrives in humid climates and is often found in rainforests or along stream banks.

It plays an important role in wetland ecosystems. The classification reflects its evolutionary relationships within the plant kingdom.

This plant thrives in areas with well-drained soil and receives partial to full sun exposure. It is commonly found in coastal and inland regions, often growing on rocky slopes or in disturbed soils. Due to its limited range and habitat specificity, it is considered a rare and endangered species in its native environment.
